4: The purpose of the model is to study how norms spread through networks. It uses a simple model of humanitarianism where agents have a certain level of compassion for others. This compassion can be increased by interacting with other agents who have high levels of compassion. However, if an agent's level of compassion drops below a certain threshold, it will stop spreading compassion to others. The model also includes a mechanism for degradation of compassion due to external factors such as donor fatigue or media coverage of negative events. The research questions addressed by the model include:• How does the presence of advocates affect the spread of compassion?• How do different weights assigned to different types of interactions affect the spread of compassion?• How does the mean threshold value of all general agents affect the spread of compassion? • How does the mean humanitarianism value of all general agents affect the spread of compassion? • How does the amount of degradation per time step affect the spread of compassion? The system boundaries of the model are defined by the initial conditions and assumptions made about the world being modeled. In this case, the system consists of a population of agents who interact with each other according to specific rules. These rules define how compassion spreads within the system, and how it is affected by external factors such as degradation. The outcome variables measured by the model include the final percentage of general norm adopters and elite norm adopters. These two variables provide insight into how well the model captures reality and allows us to draw conclusions about how compassion spreads within a network.

6: The purpose of the model is to study how norms spread through networks of agents. In particular, it examines how the presence of elites affects the speed and extent of norm diffusion. It also examines how the presence of advocates affects the speed and extent of norm diffusion. Finally, it studies how the presence of both elites and advocates affect the speed and extent of norm diffusion. Research Questions: 1. How does the presence of elites affect the speed and extent of norm diffusion? 2. How does the presence of advocates affect the speed and extent of norm diffusion? 3. How do the presence of elites and advocates affect the speed and extent of norm diffusion? System Boundaries: The system boundaries include the following: • Agents can be either general agents or elites. • General agents have heterogeneous values for humanitarianism. • Elites have homogeneous values for humanitarianism. • Advocates have homogeneous values for humanitarianism. • All agents interact with other agents within their network. • All agents degrade their humanitarianism values over time. Outcome Variables: The outcome variables include the following: • Percentage of general norm adopters • Elite norm adopters • Advocate norm adopters • Mean humanitarianism value of all general agents • Mean threshold value of all general agents • Population size • Number of agents • Average number of connections between agents • Average distance between agents • Average degree of agents • Average clustering coefficient of agents • Average shortest path length of agents • Average closeness centrality of agents • Average betweenness centrality of agents • Average eigenvector centrality of agents • Average Katz centrality of agents • Average PageRank centrality of agents • Average degree assortativity coefficient of agents • Average transitivity coefficient of agents • Average reciprocity coefficient of agents • Average density coefficient of agents • Average modularity coefficient of agents • Average community detection coefficient of agents • Average community detection coefficient of agents • Average community detection coefficient of agents • Average community detection coefficient of agents • Average community detection coefficient of agents • Average community detection coefficient of agents • Average community detection coefficient of agents • Average community detection coefficient of agents • Average community detection coefficient of agents • Average community detection coefficient of agents • Average community detection coefficient of agents • Average community detection coefficient of agents • Average community detection coefficient of agents • Average community detection coefficient of agents
7: The purpose of the model is to study how norms spread through a population of agents. The model consists of three types of agents: elites, advocates, and general agents. Elites have high levels of humanitarianism, but do not interact directly with other agents. Advocates have moderate levels of humanitarianism, and actively promote the norm by interacting with other agents. General agents have low levels of humanitarianism, and can be influenced by interactions with other agents. The model uses the concept of social influence to determine how agents' opinions change after an interaction. Agents are connected to each other via a network, and the strength of the connection between two agents depends on their proximity. The model also takes into account the fact that agents may degrade their levels of humanitarianism over time due to factors such as donor fatigue or compassion fatigue. The model aims to answer questions related to the spread of norms in a population, such as how quickly norms spread, what factors affect the speed of spread, and whether there are any tipping points where the spread becomes rapid. The system boundaries include the initial conditions of the model, such as the number of agents, their initial levels of humanitarianism, and the network topology. The outcome variables include the final percentage of general norm adopters and elite norm adopters, as well as the mean humanitarianism level of all agents.
8: The purpose of the model is to study how norms spread through a society. In particular, it looks at how norms spread when there are multiple sources of influence. The model has two main components: the spread of norms within a society and the evolution of individual opinions about those norms. The first component involves the diffusion of norms from one person to another, while the second component focuses on how individuals change their opinions about norms over time. The model also considers the role of external influences such as media coverage and government policies in shaping public opinion. The research questions addressed by the model include:• How do norms spread within a society? • What factors affect the rate at which norms spread? • How does the presence of multiple sources of influence affect the spread of norms? • How do changes in individual opinions about norms relate to changes in societal norms? • What role do external influences play in shaping public opinion?The system boundaries of the model are defined by the following assumptions:• All individuals have equal access to information about societal norms. • Individuals can only interact with others who share similar views about societal norms. • There is no external interference in the process of norm formation. • The model assumes that all individuals start out with neutral opinions about societal norms. • The model does not consider any long-term effects of norm formation on individual behavior. The outcome variables considered by the model include:• Rate of norm spread within a society • Average level of agreement among individuals about societal norms • Distribution of opinions across individuals about societal norms • Impact of external influences on public opinion about societal norms • Long-term consequences of norm formation on individual behavior
